awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Bubble fragmentation in turbulent flows
awd_abstract_narration:
Bubble break up in turbulent flows is important in many environmental and industrial situations.  These include oil spill mitigation, air entrained in bow waves in ships and submarines, and ocean-atmosphere interactions associated with breaking waves.  The bubble interface may deform and break violently under the action of turbulent flows, and the newly formed interfaces dramatically increase transfer of heat and mass between the gas and liquid phases.  This award describes a series of state-of-the-art numerical and experimental studies of the fragmentation of bubbles in turbulent flow. The goal is to produce a general model that describes the roles of turbulent flow and the interface properties on the rupture of bubbles.  This will result in a major step forward and a valuable tool in designing engineering solutions and ocean and climate modeling.  The award will also support educational activities for elementary school students, undergraduates, and graduate students.  Software developed through this work will be open source and widely available to the public and other researchers interested in modeling multiphase flows.


This work will develop an understanding of the multi-scale nature of bubble break-up phenomena under realistic conditions in terms of turbulent flow and the physico-chemical complexity of the interfaces. The break-up of bubbles far from the critical break-up size exhibits dramatic behavior, with the formation of multiple tiny satellite bubbles. The presence of surfactants at the bubble interface, ubiquitous in nature and industry, lowers the interfacial tension and affects the break-up processes.  However, this latter aspect remains largely unexplored. Systematic experiments and direct numerical simulations for various turbulence configurations will probe these multi-scale regimes. The researchers will also characterize experimentally the role of the physico-chemical properties of the interface by working with controlled surfactant and salinity conditions. In the absence of surfactant, researchers will determine how the break-up dynamics and child bubble statistics are controlled by the ratio between the bubble size and the turbulent Taylor microscale, which controls the excitation range scale, and the ratio between the bubble size and the critical Hinze scale, which controls the break-up mode and the local or non-local range of child bubble size production. In the presence of surfactants, researchers will characterize the filamentary structures that arise due to the extended stability of interfaces, leading to the generation of much smaller bubble fragments. From these extensive data sets, a mathematical framework that can be implemented in multi-phase simulations of the Navier-Stokes equations will be developed. This will allow the modeling of fragmentation in turbulent flow with complex surface rheology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Liquid droplets and gas bubbles in violent flows control exchanges of chemicals, heat and mass, critical to numerous industrial and environmental situations, such as oil spill mitigations, oil and gas transportation from remote wells, as well as breaking waves at the ocean surface entraining air bubbles into the water and ejecting aerosols into the atmosphere, impacting weather and climate from local to global scales. This CAREER award has produced a general understanding of bubble fragmentation in turbulent flow, including a physical mechanism to explain the formation of the smallest bubbles in the flow and a framework to understand the effect of surfactant on the rupture of the bubbles. The project has included the development of a state of the art computational framework combined with laboratory experiments, allowing for effective cross-validations. The project has supported educational activities for elementary, middle and high school students, and the PI has proposed teaching towards research modules in undergraduate and graduate education, extensively relying on the development and dissemination of open source numerical methods, publicly available, with broad public impact. 

We have described the full life cycle of a bubble evolving in a turbulent flow, from its rising dynamics and early deformation by turbulence to the break-up and production of child bubbles to the final pinching that culminates in a singularity. This is achieved by combining laboratory experiments and high-fidelity computational fluid dynamics. We designed and developed specific laboratory experiments and diagnostic methods using high speed imagery using multiple cameras and flow velocity diagnostics together with computational capabilities where we solve the fundamental equations for the two-phase fluid system (Navier-Stokes equations) without simplifications or models. We have developed numerical methods to account for the influence of surfactant and their transport along an interface and perform comparison to experiments. The combination of laboratory experiments and computational studies permit cross-validation of the data-sets, accessing multiple flow variables (not all measurable experimentally), and exploring a wide range of physical parameters. 

We have described the dynamical response of an interface to turbulent stresses, both in terms of how turbulence slows down bubbles rising in turbulence; and how turbulence deforms the bubbles’ interface in terms of equations describing the temporal evolution of spherical harmonic modes. We demonstrated that this dynamical response controls the bubble life-time statistics, eventually controlling the bubble break-up frequency in turbulence. Provided with an understanding of when bubbles will break, we describe the bubble break-up dynamics and the associated child bubble size distribution. We demonstrate that the bubble size distribution in a turbulent environment can be described by considering the superposition of turbulent and capillary processes, with turbulence dominating the initial deformation while capillarity takes over during the final instant of break-up and controls the production of the smallest bubbles in the system (which are essential for gas exchange and sea spray production). We proposed a physical mechanism to describe and explain the small bubble (typically below the millimeter) population in turbulence, validated by laboratory experiments and high-fidelity numerical simulations. This new theory, based on the role of capillary instabilities during fragmentation describes the time of formation and size statistics of small sub-millimeter bubbles in turbulence, solves a long- standing fundamental problem and is of crucial practical importance since these small bubbles control mass exchange in ocean-atmosphere and chemical reactors by providing an increased surface area. Through a variety of experiments and simulations, we have investigated the effect of surfactant on the bubble dynamics and rupture in turbulent flows.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 04/16/2025
Modified by: Luc Deike
